div.p: 1. IV:15. Tuesday— Shower Bath— Long ride— Thunder— Dinner party.

I took this morning a shower bath; the first time for the Season. Visited the Garden— The bud upon the Battle ground Oak has opened into five small whitish leaves. The tall Plum tree is 33 inches high, and has grown more than a foot in the course of the last Month— A second Tangier Orange came up in Box N. 5. The Second Orange in Tumbler N. 4. is withering— To multiply experiments I planted 3 yard Cherry stones in a small tin cup, to ascertain whether they will vegetate— The Sail needle shoot in Box N. 4. remains as when it first appeared— The morning was cloudy with a fresh breeze, and I rode the round by the race-ground. Mr S. H. Smith’s and the Capitol. Mr Brent brought a Letter from Governor Barbour, saying that the People of Orange County had invited him to a public dinner—which would delay for three or four days his arrival at this place. Mr Johnston the Senator from Louisiana, introduced a Mr Whittlesey from Middletown, Connecticut, whom from that circumstance I supposed, and afterwards found to be an applicant for the appointment of Collector at that Port, just vacated by the decease of Alexander Wolcott— Mr Rush brought me an Estimate of the State of the Treasury this day; after the payment of upwards of five Millions of principal of the Public Debt; from which it appears that there will remain in the Treasury a balance of four millions nine hundred thousand Dollars; and that the receipts at the Treasury for the first half year have been twelve Millions three hundred and sixty nine thousand dollars, so far exceeding our Estimates of last Winter, as to warrant the expectation that the receipts of the whole year will exceed the estimates— We have therefore every encouragement to hope that we shall at the expiration of the year have paid off seven Millions of the debt— Mr Rush spoke also of the application of judge Macomb, that the payment of the grant of Congress to Alexander Macomb might be withheld; and of the injunction to that effect, from the Circuit Court of the United States might be obeyed. Mr Rush inclined strongly to the opinion that the injunction should be disregarded, thinking that the Government could not with propriety interpose for merely private claim— I urged him however to suspend the payment, in compliance with the injunction, at
least for a few days, and to call upon judge Macomb for a written statement of the grounds upon which he claims the suspension of the payment: and afterwards to call upon Alexander Macomb for his answer to the claim— I thought it highly probable that judge Macomb could not make out a case, which would warrant the definitive compliance with the injunction, but we should then have a full justification for disregarding it— I had a dinner party consisting of Joseph Anderson, Dominique Bouligny, Daniel Brent, Charles Brooks, William Clark, John Cox Delafield, Joseph Gales junr.,Archibald Henderson, Josiah S. Johnston, John M’lean, Alexander Macomb, Charles F. Mercer, James Monroe, Joseph Nourse, Charles J Nourse, Peter B. Porter, Tench Ringgold, Isaac Roberdeau, Richard Rush, Samuel L. Southard, Stewart of New-York, Andrew Stewart and Thomas Tingey. The company were invited, with notice only from last Evening, and to meet Mr Monroe, who is to proceed home to-morrow. Governor Kent, the Mayor of Alexandria G. Graham, Charles Hay, and Coll. Roger Jones were included in the invitations but did not come— None of the Ladies dined with us— Nor Johnson Hellen— We were 26. at Table. Mr Monroe spent the Evening at Mr Southards; who invited me, but I could not go— There was a thunder shower this afternoon; and one very severe bolt.
2. IV:15. Wednesday.

Intermitted the morning ride, and passed the day at home— Judge Macomb was here upon the subject of his claim against his Uncle, and the injunction of the Circuit Court to the Secretary of the Treasury. I told him I had spoken to Mr Rush on the subject, and advised him that it would be necessary for him to present his claim in writing— Mr Southard brought me a Letter from judge Brackenridge of Florida, upon the cultivation of the live Oak near Pensacola— It contains a plan for a national establishment near Pensacola for that purpose, and much useful information respecting the natural history of that remarkable tree— The three brothers Carroll, one a Senator in the Legislature of New-York one Clerk of the Supreme Court of the U.S. and Dr Carroll, whom I had not before known called with Mr Tabbs Mr Wilde a member of the House of Representatives from Georgia, came to enquire if I had decided upon the application from the delegation in Congress, for a revisal of the rejection heretofore of certain claims of Citizens of Georgia for indemnity from Creek Indian depredations, according to the 4th. Article of the Treaty with the Creeks of 8. January 1821— I told him that the Attorney-General having been with the exception of two or three days absent ever since I received the memorial from the Delegation, I had not yet referred the papers to him, as would be necessary, before coming to a decision; much of the argument for the revisal, resting upon a difference alledged between two opinions of the Attorney General heretofore given, one upon those claims of the Citizens of Georgia, and the other upon claims of citizens of the United States, of indemnity for Slaves carried away, contrary to the first Article of the Treaty of Ghent— The first opinion being against the allowance of interest, and the second in favour of it— The Revd Mr Eagleton came to solicit contributions, for the Southwestern Theological Seminary at Maryville, Tennessee. He had sent me a pamphlet and Letter upon the subject yesterday— The peculiarity of this among numerous mendicant establishments of this kind in every part of this Country is that the Directors of the Maryville Seminary name the sum for which they call from each contributor—twenty dollars— Coll. Mullany belongs to New-York. He was a Quarter Master in the Army during the late war, but left it, at the
first reduction after the Peace— He has accounts yet unsettled at the Treasury, and wrote me a few days since a Letter soliciting the appointment of Chief Clerk to the Treasurer. He came now to repeat the application; but I informed him that all the appointments of Clerks were made by the Heads of the respective Departments— William Lee 2d Auditor of the Treasury told me that he thought there was need of some new regulation in the public offices requiring a more punctual attendance of the Clerks; many of whom were inexcusably remiss, in the performance of their duties— Probably the Season, and intense heat of the weather produces some negligence— Coll Brearley was here— He has accompanied one party of Creek Indians from Georgia, to the Arkansas Territory, and is soon going to muster another detachment of them for that purpose: but he says they will not go till they are starved into another sale of their Lands, which must soon happen; as they will exercise no industry; and now live only upon what they receive from the United States— I visited my Nursery this afternoon— The new vegetation has ceased, and I find occasion for no observation, except of the decay and perishing of a great number of my Trees— We had this day the first Apples of the Season, and I planted five seeds in a small round wafer box filled with earth, to ascertain if they would vegetate this Summer— My Sail needle shoot in Box N. 4. is a Tangier Date— A second appeared this day in the same box.
3. IV:45. Thursday. Ride— Post-Office. Race-ground. Kalorama

There was a great change in the Temperature of the atmosphere last Evening, and the weather of this day was fresh and cool. I took a long ride with John before breakfast— Abigail S. Adams returned my Seedling Pot N. 1. in which are the Tamarind, and Persimon, which she has painted, and in which there is now 1. Tangier Orange just up— In box N. 4. a 10th. and 11th. Tangier Orange appear in the central row. Coll Roberdeau and Mr Montandon called after breakfast, and Mr Montandon put in order the War Office Chronometer. Mr Rush called for a few minutes but was going to attend the adjourned Meeting of the Stockholders of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal Company. The Arrangements for the ceremony of breaking ground to-morrow are published in the newspaper of this morning, and also a notice that in consequence of my attendance at that ceremony there will be no reception of visitors at the President’s House— Mr Rush brought Recommendations of several persons for the appointments of Surveyor at New-Orleans, and of Collector at Middletown, Connecticut— Mr Bulfinch called, and spoke of the difference between Mr Elgar, the Commissioner of the Public Buildings, and Mr Foy, respecting the width of the border and walk, within the railing, on the West side of the Capitol— Mr Bulfinch thought with me, that they would be too narrow as proposed by Mr Elgar; and I told him I thought they should be of the same width as on the Eastern side— Mr Bulfinch said he had proposed to Mr Elgar, that Foy should be allowed to make first a small piece of the way according to his own idea; and it might then be determined whether it should be continued and completed in the same manner— Mr Brent was here; and I spoke with him of the applications of the two Priests Harold and Ryan, for the interposition of this Government, with that of the Pope to obtain the revocation of an order from his Holiness to them, to repair forth with from Philadelphia to Cincinnati in the State of Ohio. I desired Mr Brent to make a draft of such a Letter to the Cardinal Secretary of State, as would answer the views of Mr Harold and Mr Ryan, and at the same time not be offensive to the papal Government—and I charged him with
this duty the more readily, because being himself a Roman Catholic, a Letter known to be written by him would probably more acceptable, and more likely to be useful to those in whose behalf it was requested, than if written by a protestant— Mr Brent brought me also a Letter from Mr Rodney, the Consul at the Havana, but now at Wilmington, Delaware, denying totally the truth of the charges against him of the anonymous Letter, a copy of which had been sent to him— Mr Southard called shortly before dinner— I had some conversation with him upon judge Brackenridge’s letter respecting the cultivation of the Live Oak. I also read to him the Address which I propose to deliver to-morrow, on breaking the ground of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal— Mr Mercer called this Evening, and mentioned to me the definitive arrangements for the ceremony— The company to assemble between 7 and 8 to-morrow Morning at Tilley’s Union Hotel, in Georgetown. To walk in procession to the Steam-boats—then ascend the river to the first bridge and thence in Canal Boats to the spot where the work is to commence— Where he will present to me a spade; addressing me with a few sentences, occupying not more than five minutes— I told him that as at this time, I must expect that whatever I might say would be severely criticised, and misrepresented, I had thought proper to write what I should say, so that at least I might be responsible for nothing else— That deeming the work to be commenced of great importance to the Country and to future ages I thought it suitable to the occasion to give to the ceremony somewhat of a religious character; and I read to him the address as I proposed to deliver it— He approved of it altogether, though he thought the last paragraph, expressing good wishes for the success of the Baltimore Rail-road which is also to be commenced to-morrow, would not meet with sympathy from my hearers, as they believed that to be a rival project: but it was nevertheless entirely proper for me to speak thus and the religious cast of my address was conformable to his own Sentiments. He would adapt the few words that he should say on presenting me the Spade to the purport of my own discourse.
4. IV:15. Friday. Independence day. Chesapeake and Ohio Canal commenced— John 25.

Between seven and eight this morning I went with my Son John to the Union Hotel at Georgetown where were assembling the President and Directors of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal Company; the Mayors and Committees of the Corporations of Washington, Georgetown and Alexandria— The Heads of Departments, foreign Ministers and a few other invited persons. About eight O’Clock a procession was formed preceded by a band of Music to the wharf where we embarked in the Steam-boat Surprize; followed by two others: we proceeded to the entrance of the Potowmack Canal, and up that in Canal boats to its head: near which, just within the bounds of the State of Maryland, was the spot selected for breaking the ground— The President of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal Company with a very short Address delivered to me the Spade, with which I broke the ground: addressing the surrounding auditory, consisting perhaps of two thousand persons— It happened that at the first stroke of the Spade, it met immediately under the surface a large stump of a tree; after repeating the stroke three or four times without making any impression, I threw off my coat, and resuming the Spade, raised a shovel full of the Earth, at which a general shout burst forth from the surrounding multitude, and I completed my Address, which occupied about fifteen minutes. The President and Directors of the Canal, the Mayors and Committees of the three Corporations; the Heads of Departments, members of Congress, and others followed, and shovelled up a wheelbarrow full of the Earth— Mr Gales the Mayor of Washington read also a short Address and was answered extemporaneously by Andrew Stewart the Director of the Company from Pennsylvania.
After a short repose under a tent on the banks of the Canal, we returned by the Canal boats to the landing and thence in the Steamboat, where as we redescended the Potowmack, the company partook of a light Collation upon the deck— I was asked for a Toast and gave the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal—Perseverance.— Mr Mercer and Mr Rush also gave toasts— About half past two I was landed at Davidsons wharf where my Carriage was waiting; and after taking Mr Rush home I returned to mine.— The Marshals of the day escorted me home on horseback; came in and took a glass of wine, and took leave with my thanks for their attentions— A young man named Dorset, from Maryland, was the only other visitor— Dr. Huntt and Thomas J. Hellen dined with us— The day was uncommonly cool for the Season, with a fresh breeze, and towards Evening there was a gentle Shower— The exertion of speaking in the open air made me hoarse, and with the anxiety more oppressive than it should have been to get well through the day, exhausted, and fatigued me so that I was disqualified for thought or action the remainder of the day— As has happened to me whenever I have had a part to perform in the presence of multitudes, I got through awkwardly, but without gross and palpable failure.— The incident that chiefly relieved me was the obstacle of the stump, which met and resisted the Spade, and my casting off my coat to over come the resistance— It struck the eye and fancy of the Spectators, more than all the flowers of Rhetoric in my Speech, and diverted their attention from the stammering and hesitation of a deficient memory— Mr Vaughan, Chevalier Bangeman Huygens, Barons Krudener and Stackelberg, and several other members of the Corps Diplomatique were present, and thought it perhaps a strange part for a President of the United States to perform. Governor Kent of Maryland was there as one of the Directors of the Company; and compared the ceremony to that said to be annually observed in China— I wrote a short Letter this Evening to Charles.
5. IV:45. Saturday. Walk to the Slashes.

I am compelled to intermit my rides, and for variety of exercise took this morning a walk to the slashes. Found very few of the blackberries ripe as I was going out of the yard I met a young man who told me his name was Towner— That he belonged to Shepardstown, 70 miles distant from this place, in Virginia: that he had come all that distance to witness the ceremony of yesterday and had seen it; and being now about to return home he had felt a curiosity to see me; and having succeeded was entirely satisfied. Mr Southard called after breakfast, in some perplexity respecting the construction of an Act, passed at the recent Session of the Congress for increasing the pay of the Surgeons in the Navy. The phraseology of the Act, does not express the intention of Congress in passing it, and unless liberally construed, the intention in passing it cannot be fulfilled. But he had not a copy of the Act with him, and I had it not at hand. We spoke further of judge Brackenridge’s Letter respecting the cultivation of the live Oak— I consented that the judge should be engaged to superintend the exploration of a forest of these trees near Pensacola; and to employ from ten to twenty men upon the necessary labour of clearing and dressing and taking care of the trees, to which I desired that planting acorns should be added. This part of the Establishment he supposes to be unnecessary; and that it will be sufficient to cultivate the trees already growing— But the
natural history of the live-Oak has many singularities, and has not been duly observed—among my reasons for desiring that a considerable plantation of them should be raised from the acorn, is that their growth to maturity may be observed and perhaps a better knowledge of them be obtained. Mr Southard will write to judge Brackenridge accordingly— Governor Kent and General Walter Smith called together— Mr Henry Fry came to ask for the return of a Letter to him from Mr Crowninshield, written when he was Secretary of the Navy in 1818. which was accordingly returned to him— He asked also when he might expect my decision, upon his appeal from that of the present Secretary of the Navy in his case— I told him probably this day or to-morrow, and that I had approved Mr Southard’s decision— Mr Wilde, the member of the House of Representatives from Georgia came again upon the subject of the claims of citizens of Georgia; against the Creek Indians— I told him I had this morning referred all the papers to the Attorney General for his opinion and advice— He said he was going Northward tomorrow, and desired when my decision should be made, to be informed of it through the Post Office at Georgetown, whence Letters for him would be forwarded— Mr Brent of the Department of State came with Mr Matthews, Mr Harold and Mr Ryan the Roman Catholic Priests— Mr Wirt the Attorney General came— He returned from Annapolis Thursday Evening, and must go there to attend a Court again next Monday— I spoke to him of the Georgia papers referred to him but he had not received them— He had no distinct recollection of his two conflicting opinions— A young man who said his name was William Slaughter and belonged to Philadelphia told me that he had come from that City for the sole purpose of seeing me— He said that his father had been formerly wealthy; but had failed as a merchant and died about a year since leaving him in indigence— He was now working at a trade— Mr Wirt called again this Evening and introduced a Mr Patterson, lately from England—and proposing soon to return— I signed this day an order for the discharge from prison of George Allen, who has been fifteen Months in jail here for an assault and battery. Visited my Nursery this afternoon. There are 125 Cork Oaks up— Two have died and some others look unpromising. The rest of the plantation now yields little for observation. Mr Foy has trimmed many of the peach trees which had grown luxuriantly— I observe imperfect vegetation of 2. Orange seeds at the surface of Tumbler N. 4. a third Sail-needle date appears in box N. 4. and a 4th. Tangier Orange—crane-neck, and double stem’d in Pot N. 4.
6. IV:30. Sunday— Sun rose 4:45.

Heard Mr Brooks at the Unitarian Church, this morning from 2. Corinthians 5.7. “For we walk by faith not by sight” And in the evening from 2. Thessalonians 2.7 “For the mystery of iniquity doth already work: only he who now letteth will let, until he be taken out of the way” The morning Sermon was on the comprehensiveness of Christianity. That of the Evening was Unitarian and controversial— Mr Brooks explained the meaning of the terms letteth and let as used in this text; that is to hinder: and the division of his discourse was the enumeration of the principal lets or hindrances to the complete success of the gospel, and of the means of taking them out of the way— He considered the doctrine of the Trinity, as the principal let, or hindrance to the universal prevalence of Christianity, and the text 1. John 5.7. as the principal authority for the doctrine of the Trinity— But he said this text was not in Griesbach’s Edition of the new Testament, and thought that was the only authentic edition extant. He also said that a new Translation of the Bible would be the most effective remedy to the hindrances of Christianity and that such a Translation would shortly be published by an eminent Scholar in New-England.
He said the English Translation of the Scriptures now in use, was wonderfully accurate for the time when it was compiled; but contained many errors, several of which he cited and compared with the very different meaning of the original. He spoke also with great severity of the abuses, tyranny and oppression which have been practised in the name of the Christian Religion: commented with much indignation upon the dominion of the Pope’s: and did not forget to notice the fate of Servetus— He administered the communion after the morning service, and I partook of it— Governor Barbour was at Church this Morning— I spent as much of the day writing at home as I could; but was obliged frequently to intermit— 5th. and 6th. Tangier Oranges appeared in Pot N. 4. 1 Dry lemon, crane neck in Pot. N. 9. Also in box N. 4. a new unknown.
7. IV:15. Monday— Sun rose 4:45. Boat-Bath. Garden. Presbyterian Church election of Pastor.

Took the morning bath from the Boat in the river, and the day was absorbed, by a succession almost uninterrupted of visitors from the breakfast to the dining hour— First from Mr Mercer, next from a man who said his name was Arnold: that he belonged to the County of Middlesex, Massachusetts—that he had been travelling, and found himself here without money; he would be much obliged to me for a loan, to bear his expenses in returning home, which I declined— Coll. Thomas followed; going shortly for New-York, and his suttling expedition to Bangor, Maine— He spoke very favourably of the new Treasurer Mr Clark, and mentioned to me some new indications of the political treachery of the Post-master General M’lean— Of this I can no longer entertain a doubt— He has been all along a supple tool of the Vice-President Calhoun; but plays his game with so much cunning and duplicity, that I can fix upon no positive act that would justify the removal of him. General Parker came to solicit an appointment. He supposes the Delaware Breakwater will require an Agent for the disbursement of the money, and offers himself as a Candidate for that place— Governor Barbour came to make enquiries concerning the Instructions for his Mission— He proposes to examine the Instructions of his predecessors Mr Gallatin and Mr King, and their Correspondence; and asked for copies of such as it might be important for him to possess. He spoke of a Convention to be held at Charlottesville in Virginia, the 15th of this month, for the promotion of internal improvement—of which Mr Madison and Mr Monroe are to be members— He himself is elected a delegate from Orange County, and enquired if he could without public inconvenience so far postpone his departure, as to attend at that Convention. I thought he might— The delay could not exceed two or three days, and I supposed it would be sufficient for him to embark at New-York the first of next Month— Coll Thayer the Superintendant at West-Point, was here but I had no opportunity at conversing with him, on the state of the Academy— I received this Evening a Letter of complaint against him from Mr John Barney, whose Son has been recently dismissed from the Institution, by sentence of a Court Martial. He had already been dismissed once before; and the sentence was remitted at the recommendation of Coll. Thayer— This was the occasion of a severe complaint against him, for supposed partiality to the Son of a member of Congress— Now Barney heavily complains of him for partiality against his Son, and for favour to another. Mr Brent was here
at the same time with Mr Barbour— Mr Southard brought me a bundle of Letters and enclosures from Master Commandant Charles W. Morgan, Commander of the Sloop of War Falmouth just arrived at Pensacola, from a cruize in the gulph of Mexico and the Caribbean Sea— This vessel was sent out to take W. B. Rochester Chargé d’Affaires to the Republic of Central America and John Mason junr the Secretary of Legation to Mexico, to the countries of their respective destinations— He landed Rochester at Omoa, but instead of proceeding to his post, he posted off to the British Settlement in the Bay of Honduras, and thence back to the United States, where he arrived some time sooner than the Falmouth which carried him out. Morgan in a private Letter to Mr Southard, intimates that Mr Rochester, was quiz’d into a very unnecessary panic, by a British Agent at Omoa, and describes his agitation and movements in a manner somewhat ludicrous— Rochester’s master piece of diplomacy seems to have been in changing his ship, and coming back in a different vessel from that in which he went out. Mr Southard spoke also of the singular conduct of the two Sons of the late Richard Stockton, and with some suspicion with regard to the disposition towards him of Mr Webster— The young man named Preston, from Philadelphia, wrote me a note, and came again with importunities for a Midshipman’s warrant; but Philadelphia, has already more than its proportion, and Mr Southard’s objections compelled me to decline the grant of the warrant— Mrs M’Donald came with a tale of poverty and distress, for Charity. Mr Tyler with a Tale of Suretiship, and disasters, for an appointment. Jeremiah Brown, for the appointment of Collector of the Customs, at Middletown, Connecticut. Mr Skinner, with a plan of the City, and a project for filling up more than half the Potowmack river on the western bank, from General Mason’s Island to below the Bridge, with a view to deepen the channel on the city side of the river—it being exceedingly doubtful whether it would have that effect at all. He proposes this plan instead of a canal on the Northern and Eastern side of the City, to which he says there are great objections: but I referred him to the Directors of the Canal. A young man from Pennsylvania, named Macpherson, came for mere curiosity to see me; and Mr Handy Treasurer of the Presbyterian Church, came to inform me that they were to chuse a Pastor in the place of Mr Baker this afternoon from 5 to half past 7. O Clock, that they would probably be unanimous in favour of the Revd Luther Halsey now a Professor at Princeton College; and he earnestly invited me to attend at the Church and give my vote as a Pew holder which I did— Mr Post was there with the Trustees of the Church, and they were counting the votes which were all for Mr Halsey. I signed the Commission of John N. Sherburne, as Navy Agent at Portsmouth New Hampshire, and ordered the appointment of John M. White as Light-House keeper at Smith’s Island, Maryland. In the Garden, the Bromelia from Brazil, Pine Apple, planted in Pot N. 11. 8 May, first appeared— 4th. Date came up in Box N. 4. In the Nursery there are Black Walnuts in the North border 67. West, none South 45. East 10.
8. IV. Tuesday— 10 Mile ride— Cloudy— Evening thunder shower.

The omission of my morning ride on horseback the last four days is already perceptible to my health. I therefore mounted my horse again this morning and rode through the woods, returning by the race grounds around ten miles. After breakfast Mr Van Duesen from Middletown, Connecticut, came, with a navy Officer who introduced him; and he solicited the appointment of Collector at Middletown for Henry Wolcott son of the late Collector Alexander Wolcott. I had received a Letter from Mr Brown, the man who made the application, for the appointment yesterday, warning me against the appointment of Henry Wolcott, as no friend to the Administration, and intimating that Van Duesen’s journey here ostensibly to recommend Wolcott was really for purposes directly hostile to the Administration. There are however numerous highly respectable recommendations
in favour of Wolcott, and among the rest a very earnest one from his kinsmen the late Governor Oliver Wolcott— Mr John Rumney was from Alexandria, and applied for an appointment as keeper of a light-House. His qualifications were his wants— He lost his house by the fire in Alexandria, of January 1827. Mr Rush was here and spoke of a Report from Coll. Gratiot and Major Babcock of the Engineer Corps, upon the repairs necessary to the Brandywine Light-House in Delaware river—there is an appropriation for it by Congress of 10000 dollars; and these engineers estimate the cost of them, at more than 90.000. We thought it best to suspend the expenditure, of any part of the appropriation, till Congress shall have the opportunity of revising it. Mr Rush mentioned also a complaint of a person at Wilmington, Delaware to Allan M’Lane the Collector, transmitted by him to the Treasury Department, that the Piers at Newcastle which belong to the United States, are exclusively occupied, by the Newcastle and Frenchtown Steamboats, whereby the merchant vessels, for the accommodation of which the Piers were originally intended, are deprived of the use of them. The exclusive use of the Piers by the Steam-boats is not allowable; but to exclude them from such use would be a great inconvenience to all the travellers by that conveyance; and consequently to the Public— I told Mr Rush that I suspected there were politics in this movement, and that Louis M’Lane, the member of Congress had some hand in it. I thought the best course would be for Mr Pleasonton in the first instance to write to the proprietors of the Steam-boats, and ascertain by what authority they have occupied the Piers; which it seemed to me they should not do gratuitously; and we may proceed according to the answer which may be received to this enquiry. We had also some conversation respecting the appointment of a Collector at Middletown— There was this afternoon a menacing thunder shower, which passed principally to the Northward of the City— The plants in my Tumblers have all failed, from overwatering, and the want of a drain at bottom, of the excess of moisture. It is difficult to regulate the watering, between redundant and deficient moisture. A 2d. and 3d. Tangier Lemon came up Crane-necked, in Pot N. 9. and I sowed in a wafer box filled with Earth some fine Gooseberry seeds of 1827— Wrote to Charles in the Evening.
9. IV. Wednesday. Rock Bath and Eastern Branch Bridge ride

Rode with John to the Eastern branch Bridge, and swam alone from the Rock, 15 minutes. Mr Brent shewed me a Letter from Mr Clay, dated the first of the month, at the White Sulphur Springs in Green Briar County, Virginia— He expects benefit from those waters— Mr Brent submitted also the draft of a Letter that he had written to Mr Brown, our Minister at Paris, requesting him to make, through the Pope’s Nuncio there, a representation, to the Court of Rome in behalf of the two Priests, Harold and Ryan, against the papal Decrees, by which they are ordered from Philadelphia to Cincinnati in the State of Ohio, which decrees they insist that the Pope had not right to issue. I approved Mr Brent’s draft in which he alluded to the fact of his being himself a Roman Catholic. Mrs Honeywell is a poor woman who came to solicit a subscription to enable her to pay her Rent. Coll. Jones, Adjutant General introduced Major Thomas J. Beale, of the second Regiment of Infantry: and he left with me a copy of his paper upon the functions of the Officers of the Staff— He came again shortly afterwards under some agitation with an Order from General Macomb, announcing
in Orders to the Army that he had received from the Secretary of War, the list of Cadets, recently graduated, and appointed second Lieutenants in the Army; and the Order directs them to report themselves at their respective Stations— Coll. Jones stated that this was a variation in the form of proceeding observed since 1824. That all Orders announcing promotions and appointments in the army have issued from the Department of War, and certified by the Adjutant General. The practice had indeed been otherwise from the reduction of the army in 1821. till 1824. while Major Nourse was acting Adjutant General; and Jones hinted that Nourse being now Chief Clerk of the War Department had communicated this list directly to Genl. Macomb without apprizing the Secretary of War of it— General Porter soon after came in and I referred the papers to him requesting him to examine them, and give me his opinion, which was the most correct of the two courses of proceeding. He also brought me a Letter from Messrs. Ogden and Troup, the New-York purchasers of the Seneca Indian Lands by the Treaty upon which the Senate at their last Session declined acting, and some enclosures— I gave him the Letter from the Attorney General, asking for papers relating to the claims of Georgians against Creek Indians and to the decisions of the Commissioner Governor Preston—and requested him to have the papers looked up and sent to Mr Wirt. Governor Barbour called, and told me he proposed to leave the City on Saturday and return home. To attend the internal improvement Convention next Tuesday at Charlottesville; and to proceed from home at the close of the next week to embark at New-York for England. He made some further enquiries of the usual modes of proceeding in the delivery of Credential Letters, and intercourse with the Court. I was called from dinner to a man named Andrew Doyle, who sent in a Letter written for him announcing him as a Soldier in the late War; now blind, and having come from Canandaigua, New-York, with his wife to claim a Pension— But not being able to obtain it, asked my advice and assistance to enable him to get back— They are Irish people, and the woman shewed me a deep scar in her shoulder, the mark of a wound which she received at the Battle of Bridgwater, by going upon the field, to help the men to a little drink— I visited the garden this morning, and the Nursery after dinner— There is a Date that shews its point in Pot N. 10 planted 10. May— The English Walnut in Pot N 2. has withered irrecoverably— The tall Plum tree in Eastern Seedling bed already overtops 3 feet. The wild cherry 2 feet— The white mustard seed in the bed is near 4. feet high and going to seed but not well— It was sown too late, and Ouseley says has not acquired more than half its growth. There is a 3d. Tangier lemon up in Pot N. 9. a 7th Tangier Orange in Box N. 3. a 7th in Pot N. 4. a 3d. in Box N 5. In the Nursery there are in the Border, North, Oaks 91. West 54. South 99. East 26. = 270.
10. IV. Thursday— Sun rose 4:46.— Rock Creek Church Ride—

The morning was so cool that I omitted the river bath and rode round by the Rock Creek Church; returning by a road over which I had never before been— Mr Matthews the Roman Catholic Priest came with the Revd Mr Wheeler now President of the College at Georgetown, with which is connected the female School of the Visitation Nuns. There is to be an exhibition there the 30th. of this Month at 3. P.M. and they came to invite me to attend and to crown the two young Ladies who are to receive this distinction for their merits— They invited also the attendance of Mrs Adams— Dr Watkins introduced Lieutenant Shields of the Navy, just from Boston, where he arrived on the 4th. in the frigate Constitution, from the Squadron in the Mediterranean— Mr Owen the member of the House
of Representatives from Alabama, came to intercede, in behalf of Cadet John N. Drake of that State, one of twenty found deficient at the general examination last Month, and recommended for dismission— The report is favourable with regard to his Habits of Study, General conduct, and military propensity, but declares him deficient in the Mathematics, and of indifferent aptitude— Mr Owen wishes that he may be allowed to remain at the Academy in the Class next below that to which he belonged, and he said that the State of Alabama, had not her full proportion of Cadets at the Institution. I told him I could not allow much weight to that as a reason for retaining an incompetent pupil: but that I would readily assent to his remaining, if there were precedents for the indulgence. A Mr Gilroy came to say that he was going upon business of his own to Quebec: but as the expenses of the journey would be burdensome to him, he offered himself as a Messenger to carry despatches: for which I informed him there was no present, or probably proximate occasion. He said Dr Huntt would recommend him. General Porter brought the Treaty of January 1826. with the Creek Indians—the subsequent Act of Congress of May 1826 making an appropriation for the removal of those Indians West of the Mississippi, within two years, and the Act of 9. May last, making a further appropriation of 50000 dollars, for the object; but without extending the time; the two years having expired, the question is whether by the last Act of appropriation the agency can be continued, and the monies applied to defray the expenses of removal of other parties of the Creeks— I had no doubt that the new Appropriation was an implied extension of the Time, and shall understand the Law, accordingly— General Porter told me that upon the question of form, of the order announcing the appointment of Cadets to Lieutenancies in the Army, He thought Coll. Jones’s views were correct, and that the Orders should issue directly from the Department of War— I was of the same opinion, and desired General Porter to see General Macomb, and make known to him our impressions on the subject. A person by the name of Leland came to repeat an application which he had made some days since for a loan of money— I declined. Mr Rush called for a few minutes; going to attend a Meeting of the Stockholders of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal— They are now getting into difficulties between the conflicting local interests of Washington and Georgetown, and the question whether a new Canal in the City, shall be undertaken as a part of the main Canal, or must be a separate and distinct undertaking of the City itself. Mr Vaughan the British Minister called this day, to introduce the Bishop of Nova Scotia, Inglis—who is travelling in this Country with his family, and Judge Halliburton; but I could not receive them— They are to leave the City to-morrow. A second Tangier Orange appeared in Pot N. 1. an 8th. in Pot N. 4. and 2. Oranges in Tumbler N. 3.— Visited the Garden this Morning and the Nursery after dinner. There are ten Pine-Apples coming up in Pot N. 11. and I found the largest of my box Orange-trees, blistered all over the stem, and covered with small and almost imperceptible Ants. The Coffee kernels have now but just opened their leaves. The Tangier fig cuttings have all failed and 15 of the 17 vine cuttings have succeeded. In the Nursery I counted the Hickory Walnuts round the borders. North 58. West 0. South 54 East 13 = 125. One fresh Cork Oak appears, and three are dead. Mr Foy’s men have been trimming the chesnut trees— The self planted Button woods are beginning to shoot vigorously; but the Oaks, Walnuts and Chesnuts, have for the most part apparently ceased to grow, for some weeks. I wrote this Evening to George—
11. IV:30. Friday— 61. Ride Race Grounds. Kalorama Glass house.

I enter this day upon the sixty-second year of my age; a life already longer than is enjoyed by three fourths of the human-race— The first sentiment suitable to the day, is of gratitude for this mercy—the next a deep conviction of the duty of applying the short remnant of days that I can expect to purposes such as the task master may approve. The third a supplication for favour and fortitude from above— My ride this morning was abridged by finding the tide so high at the passage of the Rock Creek Bridge near Kalorama, that we turned back without attempting to pass it. General Porter came and took the papers relating to the Land Treaty with the Seneca Indians now in controversy. No report having yet been received from the Commissioner appointed last May, R. M. Livingston, the definitive answer of the Secretary of War to Messrs. Ogden and Troup is to be postponed. General Porter thought that according to the desire of Mr Owen of Alabama, the Cadet Drake might be retained at West Point in the Class below that in which he was admitted—to this I assented— General Porter afterwards came and introduced Mr. Cramer, a member of the Senate of New-York, and Mr Rogers a member of their House of Assembly— Mr Bulfinch came, with two written inscriptions for the Base of the Pediment of the Capitol. The object was to give simply the date of the commencement of the building, and that of its being finished— But recent as the Event is, there is no record of the day when it was commenced—the books of the Commissioners only shewing that it was between July and October 1793. Mr Bulfinch said that Foy had begun the work of the border and walk round the western side of the Capitol, and that it was quite satisfactory— Mr Gales, Mayor of the City, came with his father, a visitor here from Raleigh, North Carolina, on account of the very dangerous illness of his daughter Mrs. Seaton. The Mayor spoke to me of an application two years since from the City authorities, for a new Survey of the City, by Engineers of the United States and under the authority of the General Government— The recollection of the former application had escaped me— Mr Gales said he would send me a written statement of the reasons which rendered a new survey in the opinion of the City Government necessary. He also spoke of the recent movements in South Carolina, tending to civil war and a dissolution of the Union—and to a call in Kentucky upon John Rowan one of the Senators from that State, to account for opinions openly avowed by him since his return from this City, that in the event of the re-election of the present President of the United States the next Congress would be the last that would ever assemble. These blusterings of the South-Carolina politicians about the dissolution of the Union, are used for the purpose of carrying the election by intimidation; or if they fail in that, of laying the foundation for forcible resistance to the Laws, to break down or overawe the administration after the event— It is the counterpart to the New-England dissolution project which began with the purchase of Louisiana, and ended by the Hartford Convention— Governor Barbour called to take leave; going for home to-morrow intending to be here again the 23d. and 24th. of this Month, and to embark from New-York the first of the next— He mentioned that among the papers furnished him there was no full power; Mr Clay having supposed that there would be no immediate occasion for the Negotiation of any Treaty; but he thought that possibly a Negotiation might be proposed by the British Government, in which case
he said he should be awkwardly situated; and I told him that I would direct Mr Brent to have one made out for him— Mr Southard who has been several days unwell, confined to his house brought me the proceedings extremely voluminous of a Court of Enquiry, upon the conduct of Lieutenant Percival of the Navy at the Sandwich Islands— I had received two days since a long Report of Samuel D. Parker, who was employed as Counsel, by the Board of Foreign Missions, against Percival. It is made to Samuel Hubbard the President of the Board, and contains much insinuation, and some complaint against the proceedings of the Court of Enquiry— Mr Southard took this paper with him— Mr Thumlert came to enquire if I had any answer for his Letter, transmitted through Mr Hughes, our Charge des Affaires to the Netherlands. I told him that I was informed by Mr Hughes, that he had received and transmitted the Letter, and that I expected to hear from him concerning it again. Mr Thumlert expressed an earnest desire to make me a pair of water-proof shoes, to which I consented. Dr. Huntt dined with us.— Mr Brooks came this morning and took leave— Told me he should leave the City next Monday, to return home. Abigail S. Adams is confined to her chamber—unwell—
12. IV. Saturday. Ride on Rockville Turnpike— Sun rose 4.48.

We took a ride this morning of about 14 Miles, with which I was more than I have been before, since I began these morning rides. Mrs O’Sullivan came again with her tale of misery and distress, her children, her man’s attire and her book for which she is soliciting subscriptions— It is a difficult thing to persevere in kindness with a half-insane man—with a half-insane woman, impossible. She wrote me a long Letter some days since offering if I would supply her wants of money to resume her female raiment. I now told her that I knew not why she renewed her applications to me as I had several months since given her a definitive answer, more than once repeated— She said she was sensible of the extreme prejudices in this Country against her male cloathing, and I told her that I partook of those prejudices. I gave her a five dollar bill, and intreated her not to come to me again— Mr Cutts came to recommend earnestly Mr Nye, who is here, and is one of the applicants for the appointment of Surveyor at New-Orleans— He spoke also of the account produced by William Tharp, and authenticated before a Magistrate, with the date of 1814. while the Water-mark on the paper is of 1818— Tharp had offered and insisted upon taking his Oath before a magistrate that the date on the paper was true, before Cutts told him of the water-mark—of which he has not pretended to give any explanation. Cutts said he proposed to put the paper into the hands of the U.S. District Attorney, Mr Swann— Mr Cutts mentioned also Mr M’Kenney’s Account which is not yet settled, and shewed me a fresh Letter from M’Kenney, who prefers leaving the account unsettled to authenticating his charges by his own Oath, and talks of appealing to Congress. Mr Brent of the Department of State came for despatches received from W. Tudor at Valparaiso 13. April, and from J. M. Forbes at Buenos-Ayres of 9. May— He brought also the Treaty with Mexico, and the Resolution of the Senate advising and consenting to its ratification, which he observed took no notice of the Supplementary Articles; but as they are declared explicitly to form a part of the Treaty, there was no necessity for special notice of them in the Resolution of the Senate. General Porter was here again, upon the form of the Order, announcing the appointment of the graduated
Cadets to brevet second Lieutenancies in the army. He thought the order should be issued from the Department of War and be signed by him, which I approved. Dr Watkins introduced a Mr Tracy, an Englishman, and Man of Letters who came some Months since to this Country, with the expectation of being employed as a Professor at some College or University, but has been hitherto disappointed— He is now returning from Charlottesville, where the Trustees are to appoint a successor to professor Long, who came from England there, and has been recalled thence to the New University in London. But Mr Tracy has little hope of receiving the appointment, and complained that he had been reduced to writing for subsistence since his arrival in this Country— I received a Letter from Jonathan Nesbit jr and William Knox of Baltimore, in behalf of the Weavers of that place with a present of a piece of domestic Cotton, manufactured in the Street during their procession of the 4th. which I answered this Evening. Visited Garden and Nursery— In Eastern seedling bed, a new Oak 13— Pine-Apples up in Pot N. 11— Nursery border Chesnuts North 21. West 52. South 2. East 0. 4. 5. 6. 7. Tangier lemons up in Pot N. 9.— 1. in Pot N. 8.— Evening lassitude.
13. V. Sunday.

Heard Mr Brooks from Romans 8.5.6. [“]For they that are after the flesh do mind the things of the flesh; but they that are after the Spirit, the things of the Spirit— For to be carnally minded is Death: but to be spiritually minded is life and peace.” a more impressive discourse than any other I had ever heard from Mr Brooks— It consisted principally of a characteristic delineation, of human characters—dividing men into three classes. The sensual man, the intellectual man, and the pure Christian— His picture of the sensualist was frightful; tracing him through all the vices and crimes incident to his propensities and indulgences— By the intellectual man, Mr Brooks intended the philosophical infidel, who reasons himself out of the belief of religion and a future State. He treated this person with a more tender hand, but still represented him as the destroyer of his own happiness, and the victim of his own perversity. The portrait of the sincere and upright Christian was contrasted with both the others, and was drawn with a skilful hand and a warm heart. Mr Brooks like most of the preachers of his denomination addresses himself almost exclusively to the benevolent affections of his hearers— There is a lack of acids and of stimulants in their composition— This objection did not apply to the late Mr Little— His doctrine was full of kindness and benevolence; but he was often tart and pungent in his manner of supporting it— There was a collection taken up in aid of the funds of the Colonization Society, preceded by a few words of exhortation from the preacher. In the Evening Mr Brooks’s text was from Philippians 3.20 “For our conversation is in Heaven”—in which I heard not much to retain— There were in the course of this day two or three light thunder showers— I wrote to Charles and found the Letters and papers from David Offley, upon which it is necessary that I should occupy myself seriously— My observations on my growing plants are now almost confined to the shooting up of oranges and lemons an 8th. Lemon appears this day in Pot N. 9. A 2d. in Pot N. 8. and a 9th Tangier Orange in Pot N. 4. The difference in the first appearance of the lemon from that of the orange is noticeable. The seed leaves of the lemon are more formed on coming out of the ground, and I see as yet no twin stems from one seed; as almost always happens to the Orange. I have made one more experiment, upon the small seeds by sowing in a large wafer box those of several raspberries and also a layer of them in Tumbler N
14. IV:30. Monday. Walk to the Slashes— Few Blackberries ripe.

I found this morning the two fresh leaves that were just opened on the stem of the Apricot which has come up in my box N. 4. eaten off in the Night. The same thing had happened to it once before— I conclude that it has been done by a Cockroach. It has not yet quite killed the plant; a fresh leaf still shooting from the stem— It has not touched any other of the Plants—the 9th. 10th. 11th. and 12th. lemons appear in Pot N. 9. a 3d. in Pot N. 8. and a 2d. and 3d. in Tumbler N. 3— Mr Wyer came to inform me that the Hudson Frigate was about to sail from New-York. Coll Jones brought me the army Registers from the year 1808. with a view to shew that the form of the Order announcing the promotion of the Cadets, had heretofore been, conformable to that which he now proposed, but it appears that the practice has not been uniform: and there was an army regulation issued in 1816. specially authorizing the direct correspondence of the Adjutant General with the War Department; but which is not retained in the revised Regulations, compiled in 1821— Major Bender is recently from New-Orleans, and came to recommend Mr Nye for the appointment of Surveyor of the Port— Mr Southard and Commodore Rodgers came together— Rodgers, just returned from the annual visitation at West-Point, and from a Tour to Portsmouth— They spoke of the exploring expedition recommended by a Resolution of the House of Representatives at their last Session, and of the resurvey to be made for fixing the place of the Delaware-Bay Breakwater. Rodgers suggested many difficulties to the fitting out of the expedition during the present year; and particularly that there was no vessel in the Navy suited to the service: all the Sloops of War being too large, and the Schooners too small—none of the Sloops of War can be fitted out in less than 70 days, and with great difficulty in less than 90— The Hornet, the Erie, the Lexington, and the new Sloop now building here, called the Vandalia were successively considered, and all found liable to great objection. But I earnestly urged that the expedition should at all Events be despatched. I have a deep anxiety that this expedition should be undertaken, and as far as possible executed under the present Administration, and I observe that the next year we might not, as it is in my own mind certain that we shall not have the opportunity— The Lexington is to be got ready, as soon as possible— To proceed upon the Survey for the Breakwater Commodore Rodgers is to meet General Bernard and Mr Strickland at Philadelphia, about the first of next Month— Clement C. Biddle to be appointed a Navy Agent to superintend the disbursement of the money and the keeping of the Accounts. Mr Southard shewed me a Letter from John Williams at Knoxville Tennessee mentioning that documents would immediately be published, proving that General Jackson, was actually engaged in Aaron Burr’s conspiracy in 1807. Mr Brent of Louisiana, called upon me to recommend Mr Nye for the appointment of Surveyor at New-Orleans. Dr Watkins shewed me a Letter from C. Hammond, with one enclosed from him to Mr Gaston of North Carolina—giving a narrative attested by a man whom he represents to be of a fair and unimpeachable character and asserting of his own knowledge that Andrew Jackson, is the illegitimate son, of a Camp woman who came from England with a Corps of troops in 1759 or 1760. That her name was Fanny Jenkins, and that his father was a semi mulatto named Jack, which was the
origin of his name of Jackson— That in September 1767. he was bound out by the magistrates of the County; and the next Stage of this history finds him reading Law; and the next a judge in Tennessee— I told Watkins that this Story however attested was fabulous on the face of it—but that if proved, it would do the General more good than harm— Mr Rush was here for papers relating to the claim of David Macomb against Alexander Macomb; and for the Account of Michael Nourse as acting Treasurer of the Unite States— He spoke of the recent failure of Thomas H Smith the principal dealer in the China Trade, as likely to occasion a considerable loss to the Revenue— There were this day two or three Thunder showers.
15. IV. Tuesday. Shower and Tub Bath— Garden— College and Capitol Ride—

I substitute the Shower and Tub bath, for swimming in the river, and the long ride on horseback for a walk. It is not so effective to improve my health as I had hoped it would be; but perhaps sustains me from sinking at this Season altogether. Mr George Graham came to ask if I had decided upon a claim of his for compensation for certain extra-services which has been several months before me— The principal objection to its allowance is that Mr Graham himself at the time when he was performing the service, gave Mr Crawford then Secretary of the Treasury to understand that he should not claim it— Mr Graham insisted this morning with much force, that he has not claimed that which he assured Mr Crawford he should not claim— That he was when he gave the assurance to Mr Crawford, receiving a Salary of 2000 dollars a year, and waved a claim for extra pay. His demand now is for an allowance for the same services after the Salary had ceased— I promised to reconsider the papers, and then to come to a decision— He spoke again about employing Mr White the Delegate from Florida to assist the Attorney General, upon the appeal to the U.S. Supreme Court, on the contested Land Claims from Florida, and Arkansas— We are to wait till Mr Wirt returns from Annapolis— Mr Nye came to urge anew his suit for the appointment of Surveyor at New-Orleans, and brought me a Letter of warm recommendation, from Mr W. L. Brent of Louisiana. Coll. Roberdeau called to take leaving: going this day for Bedford Springs. His daughter Mary had already gone this morning—both for recovery of health. Mr Maury brought me to sign a Commission for Surgeon in the Navy who was appointed in January 1827 but was then absent on service abroad. Coll Ogden the Secretary to the Slave indemnity Commissioners was here— This is the day to which their meeting was adjourned, but he said neither of them had yet arrived— Mr Southard consulted me with regard to the construction of an Act of Congress passed at their last Session 24 May 1828. the object of which was to increase the pay of Surgeons in the Navy. Its title is an Act for the better organization of the Medical Department of the Navy of the United States. It first provides that no person shall be appointed an assistant Surgeon, till after examination and approval by a Board of Naval Surgeons—and that no person shall be appointed a Surgeon, till after two years Service at Sea, as an assistant Surgeon, and having passed an examination— It afterwards provides a graduated
increase of pay and rations, after 5, 10. and 20 years Service, for Surgeons appointed as prescribed by the Act— The question was whether this could be construed to extend to the old Surgeons, appointed before the passage of the Act. I thought upon full examination that it could not, though Mr Southard was sure that the intention of Congress was that it should. This intention however was not discoverable either in the Letter, or in the apparent Spirit of the Law— I advised Mr Southard to wait for an explanatory or amendatory Law at the next Session of Congress— In the Garden this morning I found a new Plant up in the mimosa box; and 16 Pines in Pot N. 11. Trimm’d an Althea, and two wild Cherries. Found the tall Plum tree 3 feet 1. inch high— In the Nursery this afternoon I found 104 young Peach trees and 13 Button woods— The last though late up, promise quick and luxuriant vegetation— The Oaks, Walnuts and Chesnuts have apparently ceased raising their Stems; the tallest being from 10 to 14 inches long— There are besides the Cork Oaks, only three apparent varieties of Oak, from the shape of their leaves and stem— The Chesnut Oak—the laurel Oak—which I at first mistook for the willow Oak, and seemingly the bear oak, which rises only two or three inches from the ground, and puts forth very small leaves— Showery.
16. IV:30. Wednesday. Shower and Tub Bath— Navy-Yard Bridge and Turnpike Ride

Mr M’Kenney came with a long Story about his account. The lying newspaper of this place, it seems has yesterday an attack upon me on the pretence that I had given my sanction to that account—while in fact it is not settled yet— M’Kenney has been a very useful and efficient Officer in the Indian Department, and rendered very important service on that Mission— But he is loose and irregular in all money concerns, and was particularly so on that occasion— The amount claimed by him including his travelling expenses and presents to the Indians was but about 5000 dollars; but in his first account, his charges were not specific; and whom positively required to specify them, he made an account claiming more than he had at first— The Comptroller Cutts, of course refused to pass it, and M’Kenney commences an abusive and threatening correspondence with him, and appeals time after time to me— Cutts finally determined to allow the account as first charged, M’Kenney making his own Affidavit to the expenditures for which he produced no voucher.— This I approved; but M’Kenney has vehement objections against it, and now complained of it as a great hardship upon him; because it had not been customary. He gave me a history of his misfortunes and distresses, representing his pecuniary embarrassments as having arisen solely from his engagements for others—the important services of his Indian Negotiations— The allowance of his Accounts by Governor Barbour and Mr Southard, and his great necessity for money, all which was persuasive and fascinating; but I told him that I had as President, no power to controul the accounting Officers of the Treasury— That so far as Mr Cutts had consulted me for advice, I had recommended that he should require specific items to the account, and that where there were no vouchers he should give his affidavit for the amount at least of his expenditures and I could by no means comprehend the policy or justice of a second account of larger amount than the first. Mr Southard and General Porter were here together. Mr Southard was desirous of obtaining some evidence of my opinions concerning the encouragement of
domestic manufacturers and the Tariff. I read to him my Letter to R. Walsh of 16 March 1824— General Porter mentioned that he had been examining the various branches of the Service in the War Department, and particularly that of intercourse with the Indians which he thought would require a system of regulations— He had thought of inviting Govr. Cass of Michigan, and General Clark of Missouri to come to this City, to assist in forming such a system— I advised that he should first write to them, and ask their general views on the subject in writing; after which if it should be found expedient they may be invited here— He said he would take this course— He has a Report from Mr Livingston; the occasional agent to the New-York Seneca Indians. Red Jacket has been reinstated as a Chief, and the removal of the remnant of the Tribe to Green Bay becomes more questionable— Mr Brent brought a Letter from Langdon Cheves, resigning his Seat as a Slave Indemnity Commissioner, because he is detained by a bilious fever in New-Jersey, and cannot attend their Meeting— Mr Jackson brought me a Letter of recommendation from C. F. Mercer, and applied for the appointment of Chief Clerk to the Treasurer—or for the Office of a Purser in the Navy, vacated by the Death of Mr Lyde— William Lee called merely for a visit. In the Garden I found in the Eastern Seedling bed 37 Black and 18 English walnuts; and in the Nursery 25 English walnuts 5 Almonds and 5. Tulips— 1. 2. Tangier Lemons came up in Pot N. 7. 4 in Pot N. 8— 13— 20 in Pot N. 9— I planted 5 fresh pear-seeds in box N. 3. Took up and replaced in the box a date Stone; no vegetation.
17. IV:30. Thursday— The Baths. Sun rose 4:52. College and Capitol Ride

In the Garden I trimmed several Peach and wild cherry trees; and weeded Oaks in the Eastern Seedling bed— A Date is coming up in the mimosa box— In the Nursery there are 64 Pear stocks from the seed, in four Rows— The vegetation of the Tulip Trees is very remarkable. They have yet scarcely any stem; but put forth their Lyrate leaves on long peduncles. The leaves are smooth and delicate, and of the most beautiful Pea-green. But the nightly insect fastens upon and devours most of them even before they are full formed. As yet the five in the Nursery have survived their attacks— The Chesnut leaves suffer also severely from these Insects. The Button woods are shooting into luxuriance— I had this morning a visit from Mr Pleasants and Mr Seawell the Slave indemnity Commissioners; Mr Brent of the Department came with them. They are desirous rather of waiting for the recovery of Mr Cheves, than that a new Commissioner should be appointed in his stead— Mr Seawell thought that if Mr Cheves should arrive here in four weeks from this day there would be no delay in the business of the Board— Mr Pleasants thought there might be some delay; but less than would inevitably follow from the appointment of a new Commissioner— The term of existence of the Commission itself is limited to the first of September— Mr Cheves writes that he was on his way to his residence at Lancaster Pennsylvania, intending to proceed thence to this place to the adjourned meeting of the Commissioners at this place when he was taken ill with a bilious fever in New-Jersey; and that his physician informed him that he could not safely move from that place in less than eight or ten days from the date of his Letter, 14 July. He assigns no other reason for resigning; but there have been conflicts
of opinion between him and the two other Commissioners, and he may have other motives for resigning than his illness— I therefore desired Mr Brent to write to him, and request him if he can reach here within three or even four weeks to continue in the Commission, considering the inconvenience that must attend the appointment of a new Commissioner at this late Stage of the Commission. Mr Seawell was under much excitement at the insurgent movements in South-Carolina. Mr M’lean the Postmaster General was here concerning the appointment of a Postmaster at Maysville Kentucky— Many recommendations in favour of the brother of the late Postmaster’s widow, who gives out verbally that he will if appointed apply the profits of the Office to her and her children’s support— A precarious reliance— I advised the appointment of Maurice Langhorne. I spoke of the proceedings relating to the delinquency of the late Postmaster at Philadelphia, Richard Bache; and expressed my strong disapprobation of the proceedings of the confidential Agent Simpson up on his own statement— Two of Baches Bonds are now sued, but the Bondsmen are worth nothing— The Bond upon which S. D. Ingham is one of the sureties has not been sued because Mr Ingham is not yet wholly recovered from a long and dangerous illness a nervous fever. A Sentiment of tenderness for this man’s condition, worthless, malicious and profligate as he is restrains me from rigorous treatment of him at this time— The Postmaster General barely mentioned the Office at Portland, where an appointment is yet to be made; and he said he expected to be obliged in a few days to remove the Postmaster at Raleigh North-Carolina, upon whom strong suspicions rested for much money lost at the Office— Mr Stephen Kingston of Philadelphia called to see me, and to entertain me with his claims of the last Century, upon France and Great-Britain— Mr Southard came after dinner, to mention the illness of Mr Cheves, of which he supposed I was not informed. I spoke to him about providing a sum of money to be at the disposal of Captain Crane— Mrs Clark and her daughter Susan went and passed the day at Georgetown.
18. IV:30. Friday. The Baths. Sun rose 4:53. Bridges and Turnpike ride.

There are in the Eastern Seedling bed twelve Peach trees which had come up self-planted in a heap of manure; which on the 30th. of April I had transplanted as a Northern border to this bed— They have grown exceedingly well, and are all from 20 inches to three feet high. But the Northern winds have given them all a bend towards the South. I asked Ouseley this morning to bank up the ground at their feet; to restore them to the true perpendicular: which he said he would. The troublesome weed at this time is the purslain; I pluck it up with the hand. Next Summer I propose to work with the Spade; an exercise I suppose as good as riding on horseback or swimming. It is too late to begin, here, where this Season is the last that I shall have for making my observations, and where my first experiments have succeeded beyond all possible expectation— All the observations upon the first shooting and growth of upwards of twenty fruit and forest trees are made— There is now from day to day no perceptible difference in them. About the last of October will be the Time for marking the height, attained by the most thrifty of each kind— I found this afternoon in the Nursery one new Tree heaving up the Earth to come out, and I suppose there will be such Stragglers the whole Summer, but only occasionally here and there one. I found 64 Pear trees in four rows, 84. Apples in 12. Rows, 120 Persimons,
113 wild Cherries, and I think 3 white mulberries, of which Mr Foy had sown a quantity of seeds, and had despaired of their coming up— The Oaks attract most of my attention—many of them have made two shoots already this Season—Many only one— Some of them have large, others very small leaves— Almost all now look sickly— Duhamel says that all trees at the putting forth of their second leaves, have a severe disease— My boxes and Pots produce now nothing new but Tangier Orange and Lemon seeds— The dates and the apricot are teazing; and neither the seeds of gooseberries, Strawberries, Raspberries or Currents will vegetate— A man named Magnes Lengss, styling himself a Soldier and Sailor of the late War came to give an account of himself and to plead for Charity. Mr Bouligny the Senator from Louisiana came to speak of the appointment of a Surveyor at New-Orleans— He said both Brainard and Nye were most respectably recommended— Henry Johnson the present Governor was in favour of Nye— Derbigny probably the next Governor was for Brainard—both were good men; both friends of the Administration; and he wished not to decide between them— He would leave that to me— He spoke of the Slave indemnity Commission, and disapproved much a late decision of the board— Mr Rush was here, and spoke of the Account of Michael Nourse for his services as acting Treasurer of the U States during the illness and after the Death of Dr Tucker—and a statement of precedents in which extra-compensation has been allowed in similar cases— I spoke to him of the analogical claim of Mr George Graham, for receiving and paying into the Treasury, monies proceeding from the Indian factories, after the abolition in 1822. of the Indian trading establishment: we had some discussion upon the equity of the claim and the reasonableness of its amount— We also conversed on the mode and the purpose of making a remittance to be at the disposal of Captain Crane.— My health is failing; and baffles all my exertions.
19. III:45. Saturday. Baths. Sun rose 4:53. College and Capitol Rides.

In the Garden Eastern Seedling bed there are five young Catalpas which Ouseley when they first came up mistook for Lilacs. I trimmed several of the wild cherries— In the Nursery the shoots which I yesterday unwarily laid bare to the Sun have perished. Many others suffer for want of shelter from his ardent gaze; but the Season has been extremely favourable to my plantations; and I have about 1500 trees alive, of this years growth, many of them flourishing. There has been as yet no drought this Season, and I have wild cherry trees more than two feet high, while none of those that came up last year attained in the Season more than ten inches— That tree is in this climate almost an Evergreen—returning its leaves verdant till December, and putting them out again in March— There was a man here this morning by the name of Ash, who came for a subscription to an Episcopalian Theological monthly magazine— Mr Houston a Clerk, in the fifth Auditors Office introduced a Mr Churchman from New-York, who said he was the nephew of John Churchman author of a book upon the magnetic Poles— Mr Brent and Mr Southard were here together. Mr Brent, with Letters from Mr Lawrence Charge d’Affaires in England, and from Mr Offley the Consul at Smyrna. He had also a Note from the Chevalier Bangeman Huygens Minister from the Netherlands whose house was robbed last Saturday by three of his own Servants— They were pursued and two of them with most of the stolen Articles were taken in the State of Maryland, and are now in prison at Baltimore— Mr Huygens applies to have the men brought into the District for trial— And I requested Mr Brent to have an application
to the Governor of Maryland made out, demanding that they may be delivered over to the Marshal of the District— Mr Lawrence’s Letters relate to the new changes in the British Ministry—the retirement of Mr Huskisson and Lord Dudley; and the formation of the Duke of Wellingtons Military Cabinet. Mr Offley’s Letter mentions the admission of an American merchant vessel at Constantinople in April, and gives a decided opinion that access to the Black Sea, might now be easily obtained by Treaty— Mr Southard had another Letter from the ex-Surgeon C. B. Hamilton, grossly insulting to him and to me— This was in his own hand-writing— This sort of brutality is not uncommon and without remedy to public men to whom the use of the horsewhip is interdicted— I desired Mr Southard to call here Monday Morning, to make the arrangements for sending my despatches to Commodore Crane, and Mr Offley— Mr Rush was here and consulted me upon some questions which relate to the execution of the new Tariff Law— Different measures have been adopted respecting appraisements at Boston, Baltimore and Richmond. He proposed to adopt a general regulation which may extend uniformly to all the Ports— He had also a Letter from Mr Dwelle requesting a final decision with regard to the adoption of his Hydrometer. I wasted much of this day in idle reading, and the evening was so warm and calm, that I found myself unable to write.
20. IV:30. Sunday. Baths.

Heard Mr Lothrop, a young man from the Theological School at Cambridge. His morning text was from John 11.25. “Jesus said unto her, I am the resurrection, and the life: he that believeth in me, though he were dead, yet shall he live.” The subject was the immortality of the Soul— Mr Lothrop is a young man, who now commences preaching; and he begins with high matter. The miracle of the Resurrection of Lazarus from the dead was performed, as Jesus declared, that the People who stood by might believe that he was sent by God— It was to give credence to his mission— But the resurrection of Lazarus, has no analogy to the immortality of the Spirit, or to the resurrection of the last day— Lazarus was a mortal, restored to mortal life—and the language of Jesus when he said I am the Resurrection and the Life was eminently figurative— The distinction between the occasional revival of a dead man, and the endless life of immortality was forcibly drawn by Jesus; who said first he that believeth in me, though he were dead yet shall he live: this was the case of Lazarus—but he added whosoever liveth and believeth in me shall never die— This has reference to the immortality of the Soul— The Christian doctrine of the final resurrection applies it to the body; but a purified, glorified, spiritualized incorruptible body—not subject to the Laws of matter: not abiding upon the earth or in the earth; dwelling not in any of the Planets, nor in any of the fixed Stars—but in Heaven, that is indefinitely somewhere in the firmament— It is a fearful and a wonderful contemplation— Mr Lothrop’s discourse was well written, but delivered in too low a voice, and without sufficient animation— He considered the doctrine of the immortality of the Soul, as supported by probabilities by the light of Nature; but as unequivocally proved and rendered certain by the gospel. With the authority of the Scripture he represented the condition of the Soul in the future State as permanent—unchangeable—happy—social and active—but whether attended with a consciousness of its previous existence in the flesh, he did not expound— The
Evening Sermon was from Matthew 13–31. [“]Another parable put he forth unto them, saying, The kingdom of Heaven is like to a grain of mustard seed, which a man took and sowed in his field: 32– Which indeed is the least of all seeds: but when it is grown, it is the greatest among herbs, and becometh a tree, so that the birds of the air come and lodge in the branches thereof.” I occupied part of this day in finishing the preparation of the papers for Captain Crane and David Offley— And I wrote four lines in the Album of a boy at New-York who desires me to address him in returning the Book by the name of Hargrave Rapsley— There was on one page of the book a paragraph of moral reflections on the approach of Death; dated November 1827. and pencil marked in the margin with the name of De Witt C— I wrote four lines on the back of this page
21. IV:30. Monday. Sun rose 4:54.— Ride to George Town. Rock Creek and College

Intermitted my daily baths— In the garden, I found this morning one of the five Catalpas of the Eastern Seedling bed dead— The sudden death of young plants, from a seemingly flourishing condition is remarkable. I have not seen it happen to any one sheltered from the Sun— And the sheltered box and Pot in my chamber are the only ones in which the young plants prosper. In the Nursery—South side, Plantation of 11. April I found the ground heaving and bursting with a Hickory walnut— I opened the ground over it, but covered again the tops of the shoot with crumbled Earth, and placed over it a tuft of grass— Mr. Montandon was here with a time piece of his invention, made for the Ordnance Department: and indicating hours, minutes, seconds and thirds or sixtieth parts of a second. He asked me what he should call it, and said he had thoughts of naming it a velocimeter— I said that would be a word compounded from two different languages—Velox being Latin and Metron Greek— If he meant to give it a name as the measure of speed, he should call it a Tachometer from ταχυς swift and μετρον a measure— Mr Graham brought me a proclamation for Sale of Lands at Batesville Arkansas, the 2d. Monday in December. I spoke to him of the claim Mr Bates the member of the House of Representatives from Missouri of Lands for Coalters heirs, which I refer again to the Attorney General: and of the employment of Joseph M. White, as assistant Counsel to the Attorney General in the pending Florida and Arkansas Land questions pending in the U.S. Supreme Court— Wyer chatted off an hour with me— With Mr Southard I agreed on the arrangements for despatching G. B. English as bearer of despatches to Commodore W. M. Crane in the Mediterranean. I gave him the draft of my Letter to himself, and read to him the Letters to Captain Crane and to Mr Offley— Mr Bouligny called with judge Robertson of Louisiana, who told me he was going to visit his father and mother who are living at Richmond in Virginia— Mr Brent came with George Watkins the Clerk in the Department of State who is to copy the papers of the proposed Negotiation with the Ottoman Porte— I gave him the drafts of the Commission to Captain Crane and David Offley; and of Letters to each of them directing him to make two Copies of each of them to be ready tomorrow— Mr Brent brought me a written opinion of Judge Cranch that neither the President of the United States, nor he as Chief Justice of the Circuit Court, have authority to demand the
